intro: Tetramolopium crepatutarum, commonly known as the desert morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Loasaceae and is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that open in the morning. The plant produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils and along dry streambeds. Its botanical features make it well-adapted to survive in harsh, desert conditions.
